[[Gallantry Cross (Vietnam)|Republic of Vietnam Meritorious Comendation]] }} [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] '''John J. Rowan''' (September 6, 1919 – October 6, 2012) was an American [[Captain (United States)|Navy Captain]]. ==Military career== ===World War II=== Rowan graduated from the United States Naval Academy in December 1941. His first tour of duty as a newly commissioned Ensign was aboard the [[USS Vincennes (CA-44)]], a heavy cruiser, which was sunk in the first [[Battle of Savo Island]]. Ensign Rowan with only a life jacket waited five hours in the water until rescued.Interview of Captain Rowan, 2011-10-15, Norfolk, Virginia After his rescue, he was assigned to the [[USS North Carolina (BB-55)]] for three months and then transferred to the [[USS De Haven (DD-469)]]. Eight weeks after his assignment on the [[USS De Haven (DD-469)]], it was sunk in the second [[Battle of Savo Island]]. Ensign Rowan sustained injuries and was in the water for two hours until rescued by an [[Landing craft tank|LCT]] which the ship had been escorting. After the second rescue, he spent the next seven months recuperating from injuries in the [[Naval Medical Center San Diego|San Diego Naval Hospital]]. While recuperating, he met and married Miss Mary Thompson (Durham, North Carolina), who was working at the hospital. He returned to duty aboard the [[USS Blue (DD-744)]] and in late August 1945 he was the senior officer of the boarding party from the [[USS Blue (DD-744)]] that accepted the surrender of the [[I-400 class submarine]], then the worldâ€™s largest submarine. He later received a citation for his participation on the Vincennes during the Jimmy Doolittle Tokyo Raid. He also served on the [[USS Lyman K. Swenson (DD-729)|USS Swenson (DD-729)]], and the staff of ComDesRon TWO where he spent the remaining two years of the war and the first three post war years. ===Post World War II=== After attending Postgraduate School in communications at the [[United States Naval Academy]] in Annapolis in 1948, Rowan was assigned to duty on the staff of [[ComCruDesPac]] in 1949 as Communications Officer and in 1952 to [[NavCommFac]], London, as Executive Officer. He was awarded the [[Legion of Merit]] for his participation in planning the move of U.S. Communications Systems from France to Germany. In 1954 he reported as Operations Officer of the [[USS Newport News (CA-148)]], and in 1955 he assumed command of the [[USS Wren (DD-568)]]. Two years later he reported to the Superintendent of the [[United States Naval Academy|U. S. Naval Academy]] for duty as Assistant Chief of Staff for Personnel and Administration. ===Vietnam War=== In April 1961, after twelve months as Executive Officer of the [[USS Newport News (CA-148)]], Rowan was assigned to duty in Washington D.C with the Director of Naval Communications where he served successively as Director, Plans and Policy Division; followed by Officer in Charge, Naval Communications Systems, Headquarters Activity; and then as Director, Program Division. In September 1963, Rowan was hand picked as the prospective Commanding Officer of the Navy's first Communication Major Relay Ship [[USS Annapolis (AGMR-1)]]. He served in this position until the ship's commissioning in March 1964. At that time, Rowan became the [[USS Annapolis (AGMR-1)|USS Annapolis']] first commanding officer and served in that position until April 1965, when he was relieved by Captain John Newland.[http://www.uss-annapolis.org/co_2_newland.htm Newland biography] As the first commanding officer of the ''USS Annapolis'', the ship has the distinction because of his direct involvement and planning for the first "floating communications" station and first ship to transmit messages ship-to-shore via satellite. ==Retirement== Captain Rowan resided in Springfield, Virginia, Pinehurst, North Carolina, and Williamsburg, Virginia with his wife Mary until his death on October 6, 2012.{{cite web|title=APT. JOHN JOSEPH ROWAN|url=http://www.bucktroutfuneralhome.net/memsol.cgi?user_id=761823|accessdate=15 August 2013}} He received a Full Honors burial in Arlington National Cemetery on Oct. 18, 2012. He and his wife attended the 1999 and 2011 [[USS Annapolis (AGMR-1)]] reunions. ==Military Awards and Decorations== ===Navy Awards=== {| |- |{{Ribbon devices|number=2|type=service-star|ribbon=Purple_Heart_BAR.svg}} |[[Purple Heart]] with 2 Gold Stars |- |[[File:American Defense Service ribbon.svg]] |[[American Defense Service Medal]] |- |{{Ribbon devices|number=9|type=service-star|ribbon=Asiatic-Pacific Campaign ribbon.svg}} |[[Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal]] with 9 Battle Stars |- |[[File:American Campaign Medal ribbon.svg]] |[[American Campaign Medal]] |- |[[File:American Defense Service ribbon.svg]] |[[American Defense Service Medal]] |- |[[File:Army of Occupation ribbon.svg]] |[[Navy Occupation Service Medal]] |- |[[File:World War II Victory Medal ribbon.svg]] |[[World War II Victory Medal]] |- |{{Ribbon devices|number=1|type=service-star|ribbon=National Defense Service Medal ribbon.svg}} |[[National Defense Service Medal]] with bronze star |- |[[File:Vietnam Service Ribbon.svg]] |[[Vietnam Service Medal]] |- |} ===Foreign Awards Received=== {| |- |[[File:Phliber rib.png]] |[[Philippine Liberation Medal]] |- |[[File:Vietnam Campaign Medal Ribbon.png]] |[[Vietnam Campaign Medal]] |- |[[File:Vietnam gallantry cross unit award-3d.svg]] |[[Gallantry Cross (Vietnam)|Vietnam Gallantry Cross]] Unit Award |- |} ==References== *{{Cite web | url = http://www.uss-annapolis.org | title = USS Annapolis (AGMR-1) Association }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rowan, John}} [[Category:1919 births]] [[Category:2012 deaths]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Korean War]] [[Category:American military personnel of the Vietnam War]] [[Category:American military personnel of World War II]] [[Category:People from Saint Paul, Minnesota]] [[Category:United States Naval Academy alumni]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]]
